G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and that a landlord who does so shall be liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,” as well as reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Springfield District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, because the Premises are located in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, because this is a civil action within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court Department, and the claims arise out of a residential lease of real property located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord’s actions that substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment of premises constitute breach of quiet enjoyment);
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlords breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by leasing nearby premises for a lounge whose late-night noise substantially interfered with tenants’ use of their apartments, and by failing to control that condition. The court emphasizes that the landlords’ liability turns on their conduct in creating and permitting conditions that naturally and probably caused substantial interference, not on their subjective intent. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s actions which substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (repeated flooding and failure to repair constituted breach of quiet enjoyment and supported award of damages);
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case directly involves repeated flooding and the landlord’s failure to make permanent repairs, and the court holds that this conduct constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and supported an award of damages (plus attorney’s fees). Although the court ultimately vacated the separate $10,000 quiet-enjoyment award as duplicative of other damages, it expressly affirms that Gem’s permitting repeated flooding interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment and created statutory liability. Thus the opinion supports using repeated flooding and failure to repair as a basis for quiet-enjoyment damages.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it… permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (serious interferences with tenancy by landlord’s acts or omissions can constitute breach of quiet enjoyment);
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that serious interference with a tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions can constitute a breach. The court explains that liability may arise not only from affirmative acts but also from failures to act (e.g., failing to take reasonable measures to remove unlawful actors from common areas), and remands specifically to determine whether the landlord’s inaction created a serious interference with the tenants’ enjoyment. This directly supports the stated proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (breach of quiet enjoyment can arise from landlord’s failure to address serious conditions in premises);
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses when a landlord’s conduct constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and expressly states that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects or conditions in the premises can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14. While the case holds that a bare statutory lead-paint violation is not automatically a quiet-enjoyment violation, it affirmatively confirms that a landlord’s failure to address serious conditions of which the landlord has notice (including lead paint) can give rise to liability under § 14. Thus it supports the general proposition that breach of quiet enjoyment can arise from failure to address serious conditions in the premises, provided there is at least negligence and notice.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004) (failure to correct defective conditions interfering with tenant’s use and enjoyment may establish liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14);
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion directly applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that the landlord’s failure, over nine years, to correct a known and serious ventilation defect that interfered with the tenants’ use of the unit and led to a fire constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court explicitly ties the landlord’s omission to the statutory standard that liability arises when acts or omissions impair the value of the premises, thus supporting the proposition that failure to correct defective conditions interfering with use and enjoyment can establish § 14 liability.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14… A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’… Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem… for over nine years… On these facts… we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.raw_text: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross, 388 Mass. 16 (1983)
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.proposition: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross, 388 Mass. 16 (1983) (discussing concept of quiet enjoyment and serious interferences);
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.case_name: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.support_reasoning: The opinion is about a private college’s authority to expel a student and the validity of a release; it nowhere discusses the doctrine of quiet enjoyment (a landlord‑tenant or property-based concept) or defines “serious interferences” with quiet enjoyment. Its analysis focuses on whether the expulsion was arbitrary or capricious, not on quiet enjoyment as a legal doctrine. Thus it does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.relevant_excerpt: “A private university, college, or school may not arbitrarily or capriciously dismiss a student… If school officials act in good faith and on reasonable grounds, however, their decision to suspend or expel a student will not be subject to successful challenge in the courts. … Violations of reasonable rules and regulations of a school are a recognized ground for dismissal of a student.”

Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.proposition: Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing tenant protections where conditions substantially interfere with habitability and use);
Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.support_reasoning: This is a concurring/dissenting opinion that critiques the majority’s broader ‘implied warranty of habitability’ concept and instead would tie landlord obligations strictly to compliance with statutory and code-based minimum standards. While it recognizes that violations of the State Sanitary Code can limit the tenant’s rent liability to the fair value of the premises, it does not affirm a general tenant protection whenever conditions ‘substantially interfere with habitability and use’ independent of those specific statutory standards. The language is narrower and more focused on code violations and implied agreements to meet those legal minima, not a free‑standing, broad habitability right.
Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.relevant_excerpt: “The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code. That holding is sufficient to dispose of the only issues raised in these cases, and to that extent I concur with the opinion. … I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”}

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (landlord’s failure to remedy conditions may constitute violation of tenant protections);
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that the landlords’ failure to furnish heat—regardless of their financial inability—constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, entitling the tenant to declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief. This squarely supports the proposition that a landlord’s failure to remedy conditions (here, lack of heat) may constitute a violation of statutory tenant protections.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction ordering that heat be provided… and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.proposition: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985) (summary process and related claims recognizing remedies for serious interferences with tenancy);
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.support_reasoning: The case arises out of a landlord’s summary process action and the tenant’s counterclaims, and the Appeals Court affirms substantial remedies for serious interferences with the tenancy—rent abatement for habitability defects, property damage, and assault-related injuries—under the implied warranty of habitability, G.L. c. 186, § 14, and G.L. c. 93A. While the opinion does not explicitly frame itself as a doctrinal statement about “summary process and related claims,” it clearly recognizes and enforces robust remedial rights for tenants facing serious interferences with their tenancy in the context of such a proceeding. Thus it fairly supports the proposition, though somewhat indirectly.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.relevant_excerpt: “After receiving documentary evidence as well as hearing testimony… the judge found in favor of LeClair on four of his counterclaims… Damages were awarded under G. L. c. 93A, the judge concluding that his findings of negligence and of breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and of G. L. c. 186, § 14, ‘also constitute a violation of G. L. c. 93A.’ … The judge’s award based on a wilful or knowing violation is supported by evidence that… there were many continuing violations, some major and some minor, [and] their cumulative effect on habitability can be considered… in determining whether Brown’s behavior was wilful.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (recognizing availability of multiple forms of damages related to landlord misconduct).
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The case expressly recognizes and applies multiple distinct categories of damages arising from landlord misconduct: retaliation damages, emotional distress damages under Chapter 93A, and diminished rental value for breach of the implied warranty of habitability. The court upholds an award that includes emotional distress as a form of Chapter 93A damages, warranty-of-habitability damages measured by the difference between fair market rental value and actual value, trebling of the combined base damages, and attorney’s fees. This directly supports the proposition that the case recognizes the availability of multiple forms of damages related to landlord misconduct.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability…. The judge then added both base awards, trebled the total, and subtracted rent withheld by Gonzalez. The judge later added to this award, an award of attorneys' fees and costs.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Under Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979), material code violations or conditions that substantially impair the tenant’s use of the premises may justify rent abatement and damages.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion directly concerns a breach of the implied warranty of habitability based on loss of heat and hot water—conditions recognized as substantial and tied to State Sanitary Code violations. The court affirms that such material breaches entitle the tenant to rent abatement (measured as the difference between value as warranted and in defective condition) and upholds a damages award. The reasoning expressly links substantial Sanitary Code violations and uninhabitable conditions to a right to abate rent and recover damages, matching the proposition.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability… ‘[A] dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.’… The trial judge found that the measure of damages was ‘the difference between the value of the apartment as warranted and the rental value of the apartment in its defective condition.’”
